div.p: We the undersigned Executors of the late Baron Sir Ferdinand von Mueller, Government Botanist of Victoria, have the painful duty to inform you of his demise which took place at twenty minutes past One o;clock on the morning of the 10th instant.

p.style: margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: 0in; text-align: start; hyphenation-ladder-count: no-limit; font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; hyphenate: false; hyphenation-remain-char-count: 2; hyphenation-push-char-count: 2;

div.p: The cause of death was Brain Apoplexy.

p.style: margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: 0in; text-align: start; hyphenation-ladder-count: no-limit; font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; hyphenate: false; hyphenation-remain-char-count: 2; hyphenation-push-char-count: 2;

div.p:
Permit us to ask that the Government will pay to his Executors the usual nine months salary.
MS annotation: 'If Baron Von Mueller had resigned his office before his death, his Executors wd have been entitled to receive nine months pay — and this payment would have been paid on an order in Council & would not have appeared on the Annual Estimates. As Baron Von Mueller did not resign his Executors are not entitled to any payment and any gratuity will have to appear on the Estimates & be voted by Parliament'.
On 24 November 1896, the Under Secretary, C. Topp, minuted: 'Is this affected by the debate the other night No says the Chief Secretary'.
MS annotation: 'Where a public servant dies and leaves a widow or children or other near relative such as a mother who has been dependent on him it is the practice to place 9 months pay on the Estimates, so that they may not suffer through the omission or inability of the officer to write out his resignation on his death bed, see Appn Act 1896-7 page 101 Div 56 items 5, 6. In this case the money is granted direct to the person to be benefited unless a minor & does not go into the deceased's estate.'
There is a note on the file cover dated 16 November 1896: 'The Cabinet decided that this request could not be granted'. A letter was sent to William Potter on 24 November.
